an10.96:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando rājagahe viharati tapodārāme.
an10.96:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Rājagaha in the Hot Springs Monastery.

an10.96:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya yena tapodā tenupasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcituṃ.
an10.96:1.2.eng: Then Ānanda rose at the crack of dawn and went to the hot springs to bathe.

an10.96:1.3.pli: Tapodāya gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsi gattāni pubbāpayamāno.
an10.96:1.3.eng: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying his limbs.

an10.96:1.4.pli: Kokanudopi kho paribbājako rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya yena tapodā tenupasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcituṃ.
an10.96:1.4.eng: The wanderer Kokanada also rose at the crack of dawn and went to the hot springs to bathe.

an10.96:2.1.pli: Addasā kho kokanudo paribbājako āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
an10.96:2.1.eng: He saw Ānanda coming off in the distance

an10.96:3.2.eng: “Of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan.”

an10.96:4.1.pli: “Puccheyyāma mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ kiñcideva desaṃ, sace āyasmā okāsaṃ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
an10.96:4.1.eng: “I’d like to ask the venerable about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

an10.96:4.2.eng: “Ask, reverend. When I’ve heard it I’ll know.”

an10.96:5.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bho, ‘sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti—evaṃdiṭṭhi bhavan”ti?
an10.96:5.1.eng: “Is this your view: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

an10.96:6.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bho, ‘asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti—evaṃdiṭṭhi bhavan”ti?
an10.96:6.1.eng: “Then is this your view: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

an10.96:7.1.eng: “Then is this your view: ‘The cosmos is finite …’ …

an10.96:7.3.eng: ‘The soul and the body are one and the same …’ …

an10.96:7.4.eng: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another …’ …

an10.96:7.5.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …

an10.96:7.6.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.96:7.7.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …
an10.96:7.7.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.96:7.8.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti—evaṃdiṭṭhi bhavan”ti?
an10.96:7.8.eng: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

an10.96:7.10.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’”ti.

an10.96:8.1.pli: “Tena hi bhavaṃ na jānāti, na passatī”ti?
an10.96:8.1.eng: “Then, sir, do you neither know nor see?”

an10.96:8.2.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, na jānāmi na passāmi.

an10.96:9.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho, sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti—
an10.96:9.1.eng: “When asked about all these points, you say that’s not your view.

an10.96:9.4.pli: sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti vadesi.

an10.96:10.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, bho, asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti—

an10.96:10.4.pli: asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti vadesi.

an10.96:11.1.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, bho, antavā loko …pe…

an10.96:11.7.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …

an10.96:11.8.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti—

an10.96:11.11.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti vadesi.

an10.96:12.1.pli: ‘Tena hi bhavaṃ na jānāti na passatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:
an10.96:12.1.eng: Yet when asked whether you neither know nor see,

an10.96:12.2.pli: ‘na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, na jānāmi na passāmi.

an10.96:12.4.pli: Yathā kathaṃ panāvuso, imassa bhāsitassa attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
an10.96:12.4.eng: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”

an10.96:13.1.pli: “‘Sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti kho, āvuso, diṭṭhigatametaṃ.
an10.96:13.1.eng: “‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile:’ that’s a misconception.

an10.96:13.2.pli: ‘Asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti kho, āvuso, diṭṭhigatametaṃ.
an10.96:13.2.eng: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile:’ that’s a misconception.

an10.96:13.5.eng: ‘The soul and the body are one and the same …’ …

an10.96:13.6.eng: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another …’ …

an10.96:13.7.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …

an10.96:13.8.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.96:13.9.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …
an10.96:13.9.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.96:13.10.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti kho, āvuso, diṭṭhigatametaṃ.
an10.96:13.10.eng: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile:’ that’s a misconception.

an10.96:14.1.pli: Yāvatā, āvuso, diṭṭhi yāvatā diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ diṭṭhiadhiṭṭhānaṃ diṭṭhipariyuṭṭhānaṃ diṭṭhisamuṭṭhānaṃ diṭṭhisamugghāto, tamahaṃ jānāmi tamahaṃ passāmi.
an10.96:14.1.eng: I know and see the scope of convictions, the scope of grounds for views, fixation on views, obsession with views, the origin of views, and the uprooting of views.

an10.96:14.2.pli: Tamahaṃ jānanto tamahaṃ passanto kyāhaṃ vakkhāmi:
an10.96:14.2.eng: Knowing and seeing thus, why should I say:

an10.96:15.1.pli: “Ko nāmo āyasmā, kathañca panāyasmantaṃ sabrahmacārī jānantī”ti?
an10.96:15.1.eng: “What is the venerable’s name? And how are you known among your spiritual companions?”

an10.96:15.3.eng: And that’s how I’m known among my spiritual companions.”

an10.96:15.4.pli: “Mahācariyena vata kira, bho, saddhiṃ mantayamānā na jānimha:
an10.96:15.4.eng: “Goodness! I had no idea I was consulting such a great tutor as

an10.96:15.7.eng: you were, I wouldn’t have said so much.

an10.96:15.8.eng: May Venerable Ānanda please forgive me.”

an10.97:0.3.eng: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods

an10.97:1.1.pli: “Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an10.97:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an10.97:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an10.97:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an10.97:3.1.pli: Bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an10.97:3.1.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an10.97:4.1.eng: They have good friends, companions, and associates.

an10.97:5.1.eng: They have right view, possessing right perspective.

an10.97:6.1.pli: Anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti; bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṃ, tirobhāvaṃ; tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati, yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
an10.97:6.1.eng: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.

an10.97:7.1.pli: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca.
an10.97:7.1.eng: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.

an10.97:8.1.pli: Parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti.
an10.97:8.1.eng: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.

an10.97:8.2.eng: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,

an10.97:8.3.eng: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.

an10.97:8.17.eng: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.

an10.97:9.1.pli: Anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhapaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhapaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti, iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
an10.97:9.1.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ Thus they recollect their many past lives, with features and details.

an10.97:10.1.pli: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata kho bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
an10.97:10.1.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an10.97:11.1.pli: Āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an10.97:11.1.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an10.97:12.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an10.97:12.1.eng: A mendicant with these ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an10.98:1.1.pli: “Dasahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu yassaṃ yassaṃ disāyaṃ viharati, phāsuyeva viharati.
an10.98:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a senior mendicant with ten qualities lives comfortably in whatever region they live.

an10.98:1.3.eng: They are long standing and have long gone forth.

an10.98:1.4.eng: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an10.98:1.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an10.98:1.6.pli: diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdho, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso,
an10.98:1.6.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an10.98:1.7.eng: They’re skilled in raising and settling disciplinary issues.

an10.98:1.8.pli: dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo,
an10.98:1.8.eng: They love the teachings and are a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.

an10.98:1.9.eng: They’re content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an10.98:1.10.pli: pāsādiko hoti abhikkantapaṭikkante susaṃvuto antaraghare nisajjāya,
an10.98:1.10.eng: They look impressive when going out and coming back, and are well restrained when sitting in an inhabited area.

an10.98:1.11.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī,
an10.98:1.11.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an10.98:1.12.pli: āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an10.98:1.12.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an10.98:1.13.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu yassaṃ yassaṃ disāyaṃ viharati, phāsuyeva viharatī”ti.
an10.98:1.13.eng: A senior mendicant with these ten qualities lives comfortably in whatever region they live.”
